alert.note: Alert for Culebra; Mayaguez and Vicinity; Northeast; San Juan and Vicinity (Puerto Rico) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS San Juan (San Juan, Puerto Rico)
info.headline: Rip Current Statement issued March 13 at 6:08AM ADT until March 18 at 7:00AM ADT by NWS San Juan
info.description: ...HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK NOW IN EFFECT THROUGH LATE FRIDAY NIGHT... ...HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM AST THIS EVENING... * WHAT...Large breaking waves of up to 10 to 13 feet and occasionally higher. Life-threatening rip currents. * WHERE...Beaches from Toa Baja eastward to Ceiba across the San Juan metropolitan area and northeastern coast of Puerto Rico, Aguada and Rincon across the western coast of Puerto Rico, and Culebra. * WHEN...For the High Surf Advisory, through 6 PM AST today. For the High Rip Current Risk, through at least late Friday night. * IMPACTS...Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions, and localized beach erosion. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper waters. Hazardous breaking waves. breaking waves.
info.instruction: There is a high risk of rip currents. Rip currents are powerful channels of water flowing quickly away from shore, which occur most often at low spots or breaks in the sandbar and in the vicinity of structures such as groins, jetties and piers. Heed the advice of lifeguards, beach patrol flags and signs. If you become caught in a rip current, yell for help. Remain calm, do not exhaust yourself and stay afloat while waiting for help. If you have to swim out of a rip current, swim parallel to shore and back toward the beach when possible. Do not attempt to swim directly against a rip current as you will tire quickly. A High Surf Advisory means that high surf will affect beaches in the advisory area, producing localized beach erosion and dangerous swimming conditions.

area.areaDesc: Culebra; Mayaguez and Vicinity; Northeast; San Juan and Vicinity
